{{BLP sources|date=November 2010}} '''Phil Nichol''' is a [[Canadian]] [[comedian]], [[singer-songwriter]] and [[actor]].
==Early life and career==
===Comedy=== Nichol was born in [[Scotland]] to a Scottish mother, but raised in [[Canada]]. He first found fame as a member of the musical comedy trio [[Corky and the Juice Pigs]], known for the song "Eskimo"
Nichol's [[2002 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] show ''Things I Like I Lick'' was nominated for the [[Perrier Award]]. In 2006, Nichol won the [[if.comedy award]] (successor to the Perrier) with a show entitled ''The Naked Racist'' which he performed at [[The Stand Comedy Club|The Stand]];<ref name="Thomas">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/13962/phil-nichol-scoops-top-edinburgh-comedy-award|title=Phil Nichol scoops top Edinburgh comedy award|last=Thomas|first=Liz|date=29 August 2006|work=[[The Stage]]|accessdate=17 November 2010}}</ref> he later performed the same show at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival. In 2007, Nichol was nominated for Best Headliner at the Chortle Awards.
On 23 September 2007, he was a last minute replacement to host the second half of the charity show ''A Seriously Funny Attempt To Get The Serious Fraud Office In The Dock.''
In 2014, Phil released his first album of comedic songs since his days in [[Corky and the Juice Pigs]] called '''Late Night Electric Watermelon'''. It can be downloaded for a small fee from Bandcamp, and [http://www.philnichol.com/latenightelectricwatermelon.php his own website].
==="Nearly Gay" and accusations of homophobia=== In 2005, Phil Nichol performed his one-man show of "Nearly Gay,"<ref name="Chortle">{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2005/p/1800/phil_nichol%3A_nearly_gay|title=Phil Nichol: Nearly Gay|date=August 2005|work=[[Chortle: The UK Comedy Guide]]|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> a show about being a straight man with a predominantly gay social group, at the Edinburgh Fringe, to positive critical reviews in the mainstream media.<ref name="Jongleurs">{{cite web|url=http://www.jongleurs.com/comedian/Phil-Nichol/|work=Jongleurs|title = Phil Nichol Jongleurs Profile|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Nichol has stated that the show was partly conceived in response to fellow comic [[Scott Capurro]] angrily and repeatedly interrupting a rendition of "Eskimo" - a song about a gay Eskimo with a rubber fetish wishing for whaleskin tights - stating that it was homophobic; Nichol stated that the song was written to "express solidarity."<ref name="custodio">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealmirror.com/2006/071306/comedy2.html|title=Non-cocksucker Blues|work=Montreal Mirror|last=Custodio|first=John|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> The "Nearly Gay" material itself has been described as Nichol "ranting about queers" and "recounting Nichol's drunken effort to cop off with a transsexual" in a four-star review by The Guardian.<ref name="Logan">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/mar/16/phil-nichol-menier-chocolate-factory|work=The Guardian|last=Logan|first=Brian|title = Phil Nichol, Menier Chocolate Factory, London|accessdate=6 February 2011|date=16 March 2009}}</ref>
===Theatre=== One of Nichol's major roles was as Philip Salon in [[Boy George]]'s musical ''[[Taboo (musical)|Taboo]]'' which premièred in the [[West End theatre|West End]] in 2002.<ref name= "westend">{{cite news |last= |first= |url= http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/10/04/38062/phil_nichol_joins_west_end_musical |title=Phil Nichol joins West End musical |work=[[Chortle]] |date=4 October 2017 |accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
At the 2012 Edinburgh Festival, Nichol appeared in a one-off performance at the Traverse Theatre for Theatre Uncut's season of radical playlets, playing an advertising executive representing a global corporation, in ''Indulge'' by the Icelandic playwright Andri Snaer Magnuson.<ref>[http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/theatre-uncut-traverse-cafe-7829 British Theatre Guide] British Theatre Guide - Retrieved 20-02-2013</ref>
====Theatre credits==== *2002-2003: ''Taboo'', Philip Salon *2003: ''12 Angry Men'', Juror 10 *2004: ''One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest'', Cheswick (understudy for R.P. McMurphy) *2005: ''The Odd Couple'', Speed *2005: ''Edward Albee's Zoo Story'', Jerry *2009: ''Simpatico'', Vinnie *2013: ''The Machine'', Mandy Dinkleman *2017: ''[[Everybody’s Talking About Jamie]]'', Hugo
===Television=== In 2006, Nichol featured in the first series of ''[[Rob Brydon's Annually Retentive]]'', playing a member of the production team.
Nichol appeared on a special edition of the UK game show ''[[The Weakest Link]]'' in 2007, featuring comedians. On being voted off he stripped naked before taking the 'walk of shame'. Host [[Anne Robinson]] joked on ''[[Outtake TV]]'' that 'it was disappointing because he only had a small part'.
He also appeared on Series 19 of ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]''. On 21 November 2007, he featured as a guest and musical artist on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'', performing a tribute to his fellow guests ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]'' actors [[Tom Wopat]], [[John Schneider (screen actor)|John Schneider]] and [[Catherine Bach]], as well as a further song to a woman whom he described anecdotally as "a stalker of his".
Nichol performed the voice of Fat Ed in the comedy puppet show ''[[Fur TV]]'' which aired on [[MTV (UK and Ireland)|MTV One]] in 2008.
Nichol is currently the narrator for the late night comedy clipshow "What The F***?!!"
Nichol portrayed [[Terry Gilliam]] in the BBC adaptation ''[[Holy Flying Circus]]'', covering the controversy surrounding the release of ''[[Monty Python's Life of Brian]]''.<ref name="life of brian">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-13856561|title=BBC to dramatise Life Of Brian controversy in new film|date=21 June 2011|publisher=BBC|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref>
==Personal life== Nichol is currently resident in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].
